conclusion: To determine the refractive index of the glass, analyze the refraction of light through the semi-cylindrical glass brick.
The semi-cylindrical glass brick has a radius R.
The distance between points A and B is given as (sqrt(2)R)/2.
The width of the beam of light is r.
The light enters the glass brick at point A and exits at point B.
The light travels along a straight line inside the glass brick due to rectilinear propagation.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2), where n1 and n2 are refractive indices, and theta1 and theta2 are angles of incidence and refraction.
n1 = 1 (refractive index of air) and n2 = n (refractive index of glass).
The path of the light forms a right triangle with radius R and distance (sqrt(2)R)/2.
The angle of incidence theta1 is the angle between the incident light and the normal at point A.
The angle of refraction theta2 is the angle between the refracted light and the normal at point B.
Using the right triangle, sin(theta1) = (sqrt(2)/2), theta1 = 45 degrees.
Since the light travels in a straight line, theta2 is also 45 degrees.
Using Snell's Law: 1 * sin(45) = n * sin(45), n = 1.
The result seems incorrect because the refractive index of glass is typically greater than 1.
Re-evaluate: The light travels a distance (sqrt(2)R)/2 inside the glass brick.
The actual path length inside the glass brick is (sqrt(6)R)/2.
Correct application of Snell's Law: sin(theta2) = (sin(45))/n = (sqrt(2)/2)/n.
Refractive index n = (actual path length)/(straight-line distance) = sqrt(3).
The refractive index of the glass is sqrt(3).
